title: 107_hr2642
content: The "National Commission on Farmworkers and Federal Health Coverage Act of 2001" establishes a commission known as the National Commission on Farmworkers and Federal Health Coverage. The Commission is tasked with specific duties outlined in the Act. The National Commission on Farmworkers and Federal Health Coverage Act of 2001 establishes a commission to examine problems faced by farmworkers under medicaid and SCHIP, including barriers to enrollment, lack of portability, and possible solutions to increase access to benefits. The National Commission on Farmworkers and Federal Health Coverage Act of 2001 establishes a commission to examine problems faced by farmworkers under medicaid and SCHIP, including barriers to enrollment, lack of portability, and possible solutions such as interstate compacts, demonstration projects, and use of current law flexibility for coverage. The National Commission on Farmworkers and Federal Health Coverage Act of 2001 aims to address issues faced by farmworkers under medicaid and SCHIP. This includes exploring solutions like national migrant family coverage, public-private partnerships for private coverage alternatives, and other appropriate measures. Definitions in the Act clarify that a farmworker includes migratory and seasonal agricultural workers, as well as their family members. Definitions in the National Commission on Farmworkers and Federal Health Coverage Act of 2001 clarify terms like medicaid (program under title XIX of the Social Security Act), SCHIP (State children's health insurance program under title XXI of the Social Security Act), and Secretary (Secretary of Health and Human Services). SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 15 members appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, including farmworkers, healthcare providers, researchers in health care financing, representatives of foundations, and Federal agencies involved in farmworker health care. The Commission consists of representatives from Federal agencies, State governments, farm and agricultural industries, and labor organizations. Members are appointed for life, with the Chairperson designated by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Meetings are called by the Chairperson or majority of members, with a majority needed for a quorum. Members of the Commission do not receive additional pay, allowances, or benefits except for farmworker members who may receive compensation for lost wages during their duties. Travel expenses, including per diem, are provided for each member. Members of the Commission receive travel expenses, including per diem, in accordance with applicable provisions. SEC. 5. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Commission, with a pay rate not exceeding GS-15 of the General Schedule. The Director may appoint additional staff with Commission approval, without regard to certain civil service laws on appointments and pay rates. The Commission may appoint individuals with pay not exceeding GS-15 level. The Director can procure temporary services and request personnel from federal agencies to assist without affecting their civil service status. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 6. The Commission, under Section 6, has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and obtain necessary information from US departments or agencies. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can accept gifts, bequests, or devises to aid its purpose. The Commission has the authority to accept gifts, bequests, or devises of money and property to aid its work. It can use the United States mails and receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission will submit a report on its study to the President, Secretary of Health and Human Services, and Congress within 18 months of this Act. The report will include findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. Appropriations are authorized for the implementation of this Act.
